items.title: Schools of Design Extend Their Reach Into Asia
items.abstract: While the potential for growth is huge, given Asia’s rising creative industries, the logistics of opening American art and design schools can be complicated.
keywords: Savannah College of Art and Design

items.title: Ada Louise Huxtable, Champion of Livable Architecture, Dies at 91
items.abstract: Ms. Huxtable pioneered modern architectural criticism in The New York Times, celebrating buildings that respected human dignity and civic history.

items.title: An Urban Standard, Coolly Reimagined
items.abstract: William Lescaze’s 1935 Kramer house, like many Modernist houses, is not weathering well.

items.title: ‘Mexsicko City’ Turns a Corner in Its Clean Air Marathon
items.abstract: Even amid other environmental gains, it is the improvement in air quality that has most burnished the city’s green credentials.

items.title: Charting a Post-Pollution Path for Cities – From London, 1952, through Beijing, 2013
items.abstract: Facing epic smog, China charts a shift from coal to gas for Beijing, and beyond.

items.title: New York City and Correction Officers Reach Tentative Contract Deal
items.abstract: If approved, the contract would include an 11 percent raise over seven years and measures that would enable more efficient prosecution of inmates who assault officers at Rikers Island.

items.title: Pritzker Prize for Architecture Is Awarded to Alejandro Aravena of Chile
items.abstract: Mr. Aravena, who has focused on low-cost social housing and reconstructing after natural disasters, received the honor as Chile emerges as a locus of noteworthy architecture.

items.title: Moving to Jersey City? Join the Club.
items.abstract: It’s a short hop from New York, and at the moment, it’s still less expensive.

items.title: New Study Finds Persistent Peril from Urban Coal Soot in China and Indoor Smoke in India
items.abstract: In Chinese cities and India’s rural households, millions remain at risk from power plant pollution and smoky cooking and heating fires.

items.title: Wesley A. Clark, Who Designed First Personal Computer, Dies at 88
items.abstract: Mr. Clark’s designs built a bridge from the era of mainframe systems that were programmed with stacks of punch cards to personal computers that respond interactively to a user.

items.title: Bright Spot for N.Y.’s Struggling Schools: Pre-K
items.abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s broader plan for public schools has been disappointing, but his universal pre-K initiative shows steady improvement.

items.title: N.Y. Today: The Mayor’s Vision for the City
items.abstract: Mayor de Blasio has already announced major policies, so what’s the teleprompter for? Also, “Brooklyn Nine-Nine” returns.

items.title: An Indian City Bursting With Action
items.abstract: The present-day version of Chennai in South India dates back to only the 1600s, so a relatively youthful exuberance should not come as a surprise.

items.title: A Guide to Antigua, Guatemala: A Candy-Colored City Framed by Volcanoes
items.abstract: With its Baroque architecture and thriving textile scene, this former colonial capital is among Central America’s most beguiling destinations.

items.title: The Old-School Reasons to Love Los Angeles Restaurants
items.abstract: An appreciation of the classics that define the city and set the bar for comforting food, skilled service and community.
keywords: Philippe the Original (Los Angeles, Calif, Restaurant)
Lawry's the Prime Rib (Los Angeles, Calif, Restaurant)
Musso & Frank Grill (Los Angeles, Calif, Restaurant)
Beverly Soon Tofu (Los Angeles, Calif, Restaurant)

items.title: Nashville Finds Opportunity in the Hole a Bomber Left in the Heart of the City
items.abstract: Since the explosion last Christmas, the city has grappled with how rebuilding will fit into its larger ambitions of transforming downtown. The hope is to draw more than just tourists.

items.title: Party for Hong Kong’s Elite Angers a City Under Covid Controls
items.abstract: Just as new restrictions were being imposed, top politicians were found to have attended a large gathering where at least one person had Covid.

items.title: When Production Design Plays a Supporting Role
items.abstract: The visual environments of “West Side Story,” “The Humans” and “Nightmare Alley” feel as alive as the actors.

items.title: ‘American Urbanist,’ a Well-Timed Biography of a Man Who Reshaped City Life
items.abstract: Richard K. Rein’s book tells the story of William H. Whyte, a sociologist who wrote “The Organization Man” and helped to rethink how cities look and feel.
keywords: American Urbanist: How William H Whyte's Unconventional Wisdom Reshaped Public Life (Book)

items.title: An Alabama Town’s Sewage Woes Test Biden’s Infrastructure Ambitions
items.abstract: The new law allocates $11.7 billion for wastewater and stormwater projects. Will it get to the impoverished communities who need it most?
